newsitem.title: JAPAN: High cost seen hindering Japan pipeline scheme.
newsitem.headline: High cost seen hindering Japan pipeline scheme.

text.p: The massive cost of constructing a major natural gas pipeline in Japan would be one of the factors that might impede implementation of such a plan, an energy analyst said on Monday.
Toshinori Tuji, the Institute of Energy Economics' (IEE) senior economist, said it was unclear whether the benefits of such a pipeline would compensate the high construction cost.
One of the possible benefits of a main pipeline would be that it could help stimulate competition within the gas industry and lead to a reduction in gas rates.
Currently some 75 to 80 percent of domestic gas demand is satisfied by four major Japanese gas companies.
Earlier this month, a private research group issued a 3.5 trillion-yen master plan for a trunk pipeline network that would be used to import natural gas and distribute it within Japan.
Japan, the world's largest importer of liquefied natural gas, currently does not have a main pipeline.
The scheme, by the National Pipeline Research Society of Japan, did not say who would fund the project or how it would be funded. -- Japan Energy Desk +81-3-5473-3706
